message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Formal Synthesis of Stochastic Systems via Control Barrier Certificates
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on synthesizing control policies for discrete-time\nstochastic control systems together with a lower bound on the probability that\nthe systems satisfy the complex temporal properties. The desired properties of\nthe system are expressed as linear temporal logic (LTL) specifications over\nfinite traces. In particular, our approach decomposes the given specification\ninto simpler reachability tasks based on its automata representation. We then\npropose the use of so-called \\emph{control barrier certificate} to solve those\nsimpler reachability tasks along with computing the corresponding controllers\nand probability bounds. Finally, we combine those controllers to obtain a\nhybrid control policy solving the considered problem. Under some assumptions,\nwe also provide two systematic approaches for uncountable and finite input sets\nto search for control barrier certificates. We demonstrate the effectiveness of\nthe proposed approach on a room temperature control and lane-keeping of a\nvehicle modeled as a four-dimensional single-track kinematic model. We compare\nour results with the discretization-based methods in the literature.\n
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about control barrier certificates:

## Control Barrier Certificate

A barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system.(no content)That is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.

### Key Details

For every ordinary differential equation that robustly fulfills a safety property of a certain type there is a corresponding barrier certificate.(no content)The first result in the field of barrier certificates was the Nagumo theorem by Mitio Nagumo in 1942.(no content)The term "barrier certificate" was introduced later based on similar concept in convex optimization called barrier functions.(no content)Barrier certificates were generalized to hybrid systems in 2004 by Stephen Prajna and Ali Jadbabaie.

### Types of Barrier Functions

One distinguishing factor is the behavior of the barrier function at the boundary of the forward invariant set. A barrier function that goes to infinity as the input approaches the boundary is called a reciprocal barrier functions.

Control barrier certificates are mathematical tools used in control theory and dynamical systems to formally verify safety properties by ensuring trajectories remain within designated safe regions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

A barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system.(no content)That is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.

### Key Details

For every ordinary differential equation that robustly fulfills a safety property of a certain type there is a corresponding barrier certificate.(no content)The first result in the field of barrier certificates was the Nagumo theorem by Mitio Nagumo in 1942.(no content)The term "barrier certificate" was introduced later based on similar concept in convex optimization called barrier functions.(no content)Barrier certificates were generalized to hybrid systems in 2004 by Stephen Prajna and Ali Jadbabaie.

### Types of Barrier Functions

One distinguishing factor is the behavior of the barrier function at the boundary of the forward invariant set. A barrier function that goes to infinity as the input approaches the boundary is called a reciprocal barrier functions.

Control barrier certificates are mathematical tools used in control theory and dynamical systems to formally verify safety properties by ensuring trajectories remain within designated safe regions.

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

## Reachability Analysis

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reachability analysis:

### Definition and Core Concept

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the particular context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of a certain number of local entities that communicate by the exchange of messages.

### Key Outcomes

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.

### Purpose and Applications

The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, but also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

### Challenges

One significant challenge is the "state space explosion." A practical issue of reachability analysis is the so-called "state space explosion"—if two entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, then the number of global states in the reachability graph is bound by the number 100 x 100 x (10 x 10) x (10 x 10) which is 100 million.

Additionally, in many cases this transition graph is unbounded and cannot be explored completely.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of automata theory:

## Definition and Overview

Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them.(no content)It is a theory in theoretical computer science with close connections to cognitive science and mathematical logic.

## Etymology and Basic Concepts

The word automata comes from the Greek word αὐτόματος, which means "self-acting, self-willed, self-moving".(no content)An automaton (automata in plural) is an abstract self-propelled computing device which follows a predetermined sequence of operations automatically.

## Key Features and Applications

Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory, and in this context, automata are used as finite representations of formal languages that may be infinite.(no content)Automata play a major role in the theory of computation, compiler construction, artificial intelligence, parsing and formal verification.

## Historical Development

The theory of abstract automata was developed in the mid-20th century in connection with finite automata.(no content)1956 saw the publication of Automata Studies, which collected work by scientists including Claude Shannon, W. Ross Ashby, John von Neumann, Marvin Minsky, Edward F. Moore, and Stephen Cole Kleene. With the publication of this volume, "automata theory emerged as a relatively autonomous discipline".

## Types of Automata

An automaton with a finite number of states is called a finite automaton (FA) or finite-state machine (FSM). Additionally, automata theory encompasses other types such as pushdown automata, Turing machines, cellular automata, and hybrid automata used in various computational contexts.

Here are the search results for Linear Temporal Logic (LTL):

## Overview

Linear temporal logic (LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time.(no content)In LTL, one can encode formulae about the future of paths, such as expressing that a condition will eventually be true, or that a condition will be true until another fact becomes true.

## Key Characteristics

Linear-time logics are restricted to reasoning about a single timeline, whereas branching-time logics can reason about multiple timelines.(no content)LTL formulae are commonly used to express constraints, specifications, or processes that a system should follow.

## Applications and Computational Complexity

The field of model checking aims to formally verify whether a system meets a given specification, and in automata-theoretic model checking, both the system and specification are expressed as separate finite-state machines and then compared.(no content)Model checking and satisfiability against an LTL formula are PSPACE-complete problems.

## Relationship to Other Logics

Computation tree logic (CTL) and linear temporal logic (LTL) are both a subset of CTL*, but are incomparable.(no content)LTL can be shown to be equivalent to the monadic first-order logic of order, FO[<]—a result known as Kamp's theorem—or equivalently to star-free languages.

Linear-time logics are restricted to reasoning about a single timeline, whereas branching-time logics can reason about multiple timelines.(no content)LTL formulae are commonly used to express constraints, specifications, or processes that a system should follow.

## Applications and Computational Complexity

The field of model checking aims to formally verify whether a system meets a given specification, and in automata-theoretic model checking, both the system and specification are expressed as separate finite-state machines and then compared.(no content)Model checking and satisfiability against an LTL formula are PSPACE-complete problems.

## Relationship to Other Logics

Computation tree logic (CTL) and linear temporal logic (LTL) are both a subset of CTL*, but are incomparable.(no content)LTL can be shown to be equivalent to the monadic first-order logic of order, FO[<]—a result known as Kamp's theorem—or equivalently to star-free languages.

Links: [{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear%E2%80%93quadratic%E2%80%93Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_systems_engineering"},{"title":"Stochastic dynamic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_dynamic_programming"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Category:Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Control_theory"}]

I found comprehensive information about stochastic control systems. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition

Stochastic control or stochastic optimal control is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.

## Key Characteristics

A stochastic control problem is one in which the evolution of the state variables is subjected to random shocks from outside the system.(no content)In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumedthat there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.

## Important Principles

A fundamental concept in stochastic control is the separation principle, which states that the problems of optimal control and state estimation can be decoupled under certain conditions. One important application is linear-quadratic-Gaussian control, where when process and observation noise are Gaussian, the optimal solution separates into a Kalman filter and a linear-quadratic regulator.

## Historical Development

The field of stochastic control has developed greatly since the 1970s, particularly in its applications to finance.(no content)Robert Merton used stochastic control to study optimal portfolios of safe and risky assets.

## Solution Methods

Stochastic dynamic programming, originally introduced by Richard E. Bellman, is a technique for modelling and solving problems of decision making under uncertainty, representing the problem in the form of a Bellman equation with the aim to compute a policy prescribing how to act optimally in the face of uncertainty.

I've completed a web search for "Kinematic model vehicle" and found relevant information. Here's what the search results show:

## Overview of Kinematic Models

In physics, kinematics studies the geometrical aspects of motion of physical objects independent of forces that set them in motion. When applied to vehicles, kinematic models are used to describe how vehicles move and behave.

## Vehicle Dynamics and Kinematic Modeling

Vehicle dynamics is the study of vehicle motion, e.g., how a vehicle's forward movement changes in response to driver inputs, propulsion system outputs, ambient conditions, air/surface/water conditions, etc.(no content)This can be as straightforward as a simple spring mass system, through a three-degree of freedom (DoF) bicycle model, to a large degree of complexity using a multibody system simulation package such as MSC ADAMS or Modelica.

## Applications in Planning and Control

In robotics and autonomous systems, kinematic models are essential for planning vehicle motion. In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

The search results indicate that kinematic vehicle models range from simple mathematical representations to complex simulations used in vehicle engineering and autonomous vehicle applications.

Web search results for query: "Temperature control HVAC"

Links: [{"title":"HVAC control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HVAC_control_system"},{"title":"Thermostat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermostat"},{"title":"Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heating,_ventilation,_and_air_conditioning"},{"title":"Window fan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_fan"}]

I've performed the web search for "Temperature control HVAC". Here are the key findings:

## HVAC Temperature Control Overview

HVAC (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning) equipment needs a control system to regulate the operation of a heating and/or air conditioning system.

## How Temperature Control Works

A sensing device is used to compare the actual temperature with a target state, and then the control system draws a conclusion what action has to be taken, such as starting the blower.

## Control Technologies

Central controllers and most terminal unit controllers are programmable, with features including time schedules, set points, controllers, logic, timers, trend logs, and alarms.(no content)By the year 2000, computerized controllers were common, and today some of these controllers can be accessed by web browsers.

## Thermostats

A thermostat exerts control by switching heating or cooling devices on or off, or by regulating the flow of a heat transfer fluid as needed, to maintain the correct temperature.(no content)Digital thermostats use either a relay or a semiconductor device such as triac to act as a switch to control the HVAC unit.

## Advanced Systems

Zones are controlled by multiple thermostats, and in forced air systems they control zone dampers inside the vents which selectively block the flow of air.

HVAC (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning) equipment needs a control system to regulate the operation of a heating and/or air conditioning system.

## How Temperature Control Works

A sensing device is used to compare the actual temperature with a target state, and then the control system draws a conclusion what action has to be taken, such as starting the blower.

## Control Technologies

Central controllers and most terminal unit controllers are programmable, with features including time schedules, set points, controllers, logic, timers, trend logs, and alarms.(no content)By the year 2000, computerized controllers were common, and today some of these controllers can be accessed by web browsers.

## Thermostats

A thermostat exerts control by switching heating or cooling devices on or off, or by regulating the flow of a heat transfer fluid as needed, to maintain the correct temperature.(no content)Digital thermostats use either a relay or a semiconductor device such as triac to act as a switch to control the HVAC unit.

## Advanced Systems

Zones are controlled by multiple thermostats, and in forced air systems they control zone dampers inside the vents which selectively block the flow of air.

Based on the search results, "Control policy" can refer to several different concepts depending on context:

## General Definition
A control policy is a deliberate system of guidelines to guide decisions and achieve rational outcomes, and is implemented as a procedure or protocol.

## Specific Types of Control Policies

**Command and Control Regulation**: Command and Control in regulation involves the government or similar body to "command" the reduction of pollution (e.g. setting emissions levels) and to "control" the manner in which it is achieved (e.g. by installing pollution-control technologies).

**Access Control Policy**: Access control policy (also access policy) is part of an organization's security policy. This involves managing who can access specific resources or systems within an organization.

**Internal Control Policy**: Internal control, as defined by accounting and auditing, is a process for assuring of an organization's objectives in operational effectiveness and efficiency, reliable financial reporting, and compliance with laws, regulations and policies.

**Production Control Policy**: Constant work in process or CONWIP are pull-oriented production control systems.

The specific meaning of "control policy" depends on the context in which it is used, whether in environmental regulation, cybersecurity, accounting, manufacturing, or other organizational settings.

Links: [{"title":"Discretization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discretization"},{"title":"Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_methods_for_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Discretization of continuous features - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discretization_of_continuous_features"},{"title":"Discretization error - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discretization_error"},{"title":"Gradient discretisation method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_discretisation_method"},{"title":"Finite difference method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_difference_method"},{"title":"Temporal discretization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_discretization"},{"title":"Method of lines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Method_of_lines"},{"title":"Numerical analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_analysis"},{"title":"Numerical methods in fluid mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_methods_in_fluid_mechanics"}]

I've completed a web search for "Discretization numerical methods." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

In applied mathematics, discretization is the process of transferring continuous functions, models, variables, and equations into discrete counterparts. This process is usually carried out as a first step toward making them suitable for numerical evaluation and implementation on digital computers.

## Common Discretization Methods

Several important numerical discretization techniques include:

1. **Finite Difference Method (FDM)**: Finite-difference methods are a class of numerical techniques for solving differential equations by approximating derivatives with finite differences.

2. **Finite Element Method (FEM)**: The finite element method is a numerical technique for finding approximate solutions to boundary value problems for differential equations. It uses variational methods (the calculus of variations) to minimize an error function and produce a stable solution. FEM encompasses all the methods for connecting many simple element equations over many small subdomains, named finite elements, to approximate a more complex equation over a larger domain.

3. **Finite Volume Method**: The finite-volume method is a numerical technique for representing and evaluating partial differential equations in the form of algebraic equations.

4. **Method of Lines**: The method of lines is a technique for solving partial differential equations in which all but one dimension is discretized. By reducing a PDE to a single continuous dimension, the method of lines allows solutions to be computed via methods and software developed for the numerical integration of ordinary differential equations and differential-algebraic systems of equations.

## Related Concepts

Whenever continuous data is discretized, there is always some amount of discretization error.(no content)In numerical analysis, computational physics, and simulation, discretization error is the error resulting from the fact that a function of a continuous variable is represented in the computer by a finite number of evaluations, for example, on a lattice.

Links: [{"title":"Lane departure warning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_departure_warning_system"},{"title":"Lane centering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_centering"},{"title":"Automated lane keeping systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_lane_keeping_systems"},{"title":"Advanced driver-assistance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_driver-assistance_system"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Lane control lights - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_control_lights"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Road safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road-traffic_safety"},{"title":"Traffic law in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_law_in_the_United_States"}]

I've completed the web search for "Lane keeping vehicle control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Lane keeping, also known as lane centering assist, lane assist, auto steer or autosteer, is an advanced driver-assistance system that keeps a road vehicle centered in the lane, relieving the driver of the task of steering.

## Types of Lane Keeping Systems

A lane keeping assist mechanism can either reactively turn a vehicle back into the lane if it starts to leave or proactively keep the vehicle in the center of the lane.(no content)Lane keeping assist (LKA) is a feature that, in addition to the lane departure warning system, automatically takes steps to ensure the vehicle stays in its lane.

## How It Works

Lane centering assists the driver in keeping the vehicle centered in a lane. A lane-centering system may autonomously take over the steering when it determines the driver is at risk of deterring from the lane. This system uses cameras to monitor lane markings to stay within a safe distance between both sides of the lane.

## Safety Benefits

Lane keeping assistance is shown to offer a reduction potential of 19% in crashes.(no content)Two separate studies found that lane-keeping systems and blind spot monitoring systems had lower crash rates than the same vehicles without the systems. Police crash data from 25 states between 2009 and 2015 reduced rates of single-vehicle, sideswipe, and head-on crashes by 11 percent, and injuries in such crashes by 21 percent.

## Limitations

Lane departure warning systems and lane keeping systems rely on visible lane markings. They typically cannot decipher faded, missing, or incorrect lane markings. Markings covered in snow or old lane markings left visible can hinder the ability of the system.

## Overview

Lane keeping, also known as lane centering assist, lane assist, auto steer or autosteer, is an advanced driver-assistance system that keeps a road vehicle centered in the lane, relieving the driver of the task of steering.

## Types of Lane Keeping Systems

A lane keeping assist mechanism can either reactively turn a vehicle back into the lane if it starts to leave or proactively keep the vehicle in the center of the lane.(no content)Lane keeping assist (LKA) is a feature that, in addition to the lane departure warning system, automatically takes steps to ensure the vehicle stays in its lane.

## How It Works

Lane centering assists the driver in keeping the vehicle centered in a lane. A lane-centering system may autonomously take over the steering when it determines the driver is at risk of deterring from the lane. This system uses cameras to monitor lane markings to stay within a safe distance between both sides of the lane.

## Safety Benefits

Lane keeping assistance is shown to offer a reduction potential of 19% in crashes.(no content)Two separate studies found that lane-keeping systems and blind spot monitoring systems had lower crash rates than the same vehicles without the systems. Police crash data from 25 states between 2009 and 2015 reduced rates of single-vehicle, sideswipe, and head-on crashes by 11 percent, and injuries in such crashes by 21 percent.

## Limitations

Lane departure warning systems and lane keeping systems rely on visible lane markings. They typically cannot decipher faded, missing, or incorrect lane markings. Markings covered in snow or old lane markings left visible can hinder the ability of the system.
